questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 1:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and the repeated phrases of grief and prayer.
tips: Notice the three times Nehemiah says 'I am' (v.1, 3, 6) showing his identification with the city
Pay attention to the phrase 'the city of the LORD' (v.2) which emphasizes God's covenant relationship
The repeated 'I have wept' (v.3) shows the depth of his sorrow

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (Nehemiah), what (prays for Jerusalem), where (in the city of Jerusalem), and why (the walls are broken and gates burned).
tips: Include that Nehemiah was the cupbearer to the Persian king
Note the immediate response: he wept, mourned, fasted, and prayed for days
His prayer includes confession of Israel's sins and a plea for God's restoration

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Nehemiah's grief (v.3), his confession of sins (v.4-5), or his plea for God's help (v.6-11)?
tips: The phrase 'the city of the LORD is broken' (v.2) is a powerful image of divine abandonment
Nehemiah's confession of his own family's sins (v.5) shows deep humility
The request for God to 'remember the covenant' (v.9) is a key plea for restoration

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about the need for repentance and intercession for Jerusalem?
tips: He emphasizes that the city is broken because of sin, not just physical destruction
The prayer shows that God's covenant with Israel is still active and requires restoration
This passage models how to pray for God's city when it is in trouble

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The role of the cupbearer, why Nehemiah confesses his family's sins, and the meaning of 'the city of the LORD'?
tips: Cupbearer in Persia: Nehemiah was a high official who managed the king's wine and food, which gave him access to the king
Nehemiah confesses his family's sins because the covenant is collective; even the leadership must be accountable
'The city of the LORD' refers to Jerusalem as the holy city where God's presence is promised, not just a physical city

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice grief for God's broken city this week? What specific sin in your life or community needs confession?
tips: Consider an area where you feel God's city is broken (e.g., church, family, society)
Pray for the brokenness and confess it, like Nehemiah did
Take one step to repair the brokenness by praying for restoration

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His covenant faithfulness. Ask for the courage to weep over Jerusalem's broken state and to pray for restoration.
tips: Thank God for the promise of restoration in His covenant
Pray for the strength to confess your own sins and the sins of the church
Ask God to send a team of intercessors like Nehemiah

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Nehemiah 2 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 3:1-32 aloud, paying attention to the names of the gates and the descriptions of who rebuilt what section.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the wall' and the sequence of gates (e.g., Sheep Gate, then the gate of the people of the city)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the nobles of Tekoa would not stoop to serve' (v.26) which shows a specific refusal
The emotional tone shifts from organized effort to a moment of tension with the nobles

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO does WHAT, WHERE, and WHY.
tips: Include the starting point: Sheep Gate (v.1)
Note the nobles of Tekoa refusing to work (v.26) as a key event
Describe how the wall was built from the Sheep Gate and then around the city (v.1-2)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the coordinated labor (v.1-2), the nobles of Tekoa refusing to serve (v.26), or the detail about families working near their homes (v.2-7).
tips: The nobles of Tekoa's refusal is a powerful contrast to the rest of the builders, showing pride that refuses service
The detail of families working near their homes (e.g., the gate of the people of the city) shows practical, local involvement
The sequence of gates (from Sheep Gate to the gate of the people of the city) demonstrates careful organization

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about the importance of unified, humble service in rebuilding their community?
tips: Nehemiah emphasizes that the wall is built by diverse groups (priests, nobles, craftsmen, families) to show that God's work requires all
The nobles of Tekoa's refusal serves as a warning against pride that hinders community work
This passage foreshadows the church being built by diverse believers, each doing their part without pride

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The specific gate names, why the nobles of Tekoa refused to work, and the difference between rebuilding and repairing.
tips: The gates in ancient Jerusalem had specific names (e.g., Sheep Gate) that were used for trade and access; the text lists 12 gates
The nobles of Tekoa were a local group (a town near Jerusalem) and their refusal was likely due to pride or a misunderstanding of the task
The chapter uses 'rebuild' (for sections that were not yet built) and 'repair' (for sections that were already partially built) to show the extent of the work

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you actively do your part in a community project this week without pride, like the builders in Nehemiah 3?
tips: Identify a small task in your church, family, or neighborhood that you can do without expecting others to do it
Reflect on the nobles of Tekoa: when have you been unwilling to help without a reason?
Practice 'doing your part' by helping a neighbor or family member without being asked

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for the example of humble service in the church. Ask for the strength to work without pride and to help others without hesitation.
tips: Thank God for the wall of community that He builds through humble service
Pray for the courage to serve without pride, especially when it's difficult
Ask for the grace to see others as part of the work, not obstacles

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 4:1-21 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Nehemiah and the enemies, and the description of the armed vigilance.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'our God' in the declaration (v.21)
Pay attention to the contrast between the enemies' threats (v.1-2) and the workers' vigilance (v.7-12)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Nehemiah takes these actions.
tips: Include Sanballat and Tobiah's mocking threats (v.1-2)
Note the workers carrying weapons in one hand and building with the other (v.9-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the enemies' threats (v.1-2), Nehemiah's prayer and guard strategy (v.3-4), the workers' dual burden (v.9-10), or the declaration (v.21)?
tips: The workers carrying heavy loads with one hand and weapons in the other (v.9-10) shows incredible commitment
The phrase 'our God will fight for us' (v.21) is a powerful declaration of trust in God's protection

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about how to respond to opposition and threats?
tips: Nehemiah emphasizes that faith in God's protection should drive practical preparation and vigilance
This passage shows that true security comes from God's presence, not human strength

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reason for the armed vigilance, the cultural context of the enemies, or the theological concept of God fighting for us?
tips: In ancient Israel, the idea of 'God fighting for us' (v.21) was not common in military contexts; it was a unique promise for the exiles
The enemies (Sanballat and Tobiah) were powerful rulers who could have easily destroyed the city without waiting for the workers to finish

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the principle of 'working and watching' (v.9-10) to a current challenge this week?
tips: Think about a task where you have to be both productive and vigilant
Consider how you can be prepared for potential threats in your life or work

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His protection and ask for the strength to be both vigilant and faithful in your work.
tips: Thank God for providing the strength to face opposition
Ask God to help you declare 'Our God will fight for us' when you face challenges

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 5:1-19 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone of the injustice and the resolution.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'they' (vv. 1-3) to show the widespread problem
Pay attention to the phrase 'they have taken fields and vineyards' (v. 4) for the severity of exploitation
The phrase 'I have been a servant of the Lord' (v. 17) shows Nehemiah's humility

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the returned exiles), WHAT (the internal injustice of debt and exploitation), WHEN (during the rebuilding of Jerusalem), WHERE (in the city of Jerusalem), and WHY (to address economic crisis and restore justice).
tips: Include the rich charging interest to the poor (v. 1-3)
Note Nehemiah's rebuke of the nobles and officials (v. 6-9)
Mention the agreement to return fields and vineyards (v. 10-19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of the exploitation (v. 1-3), Nehemiah's rebuke (v. 6-9), or his personal sacrifice (v. 17-19)?
tips: The phrase 'they have taken fields and vineyards' (v. 4) shows the severe economic exploitation
Nehemiah's refusal of his food allowance and feeding 150 people (v. 17-19) demonstrates his humility and care for the poor
The nobles and officials agreeing to return what they took (v. 10-19) shows the resolution of the crisis

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about economic justice and leadership?
tips: Nehemiah addresses the immediate crisis of exploitation to restore trust in the community and God
The focus is on the responsibility of leaders to care for the poor and the importance of fear of God over material gain
This passage foreshadows Christ's concern for the poor and his sacrifice

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of 'debt slavery', the cultural context of usury in ancient Israel, or the role of the nobles in the community?
tips: In ancient Israel, usury was prohibited for the poor by law (Deuteronomy 23:19), but the rich were exploiting the poor by taking fields and vineyards (v. 4)
The term 'debt slavery' (v. 1-3) refers to the practice where the poor could become slaves if they couldn't pay debts
The nobles and officials had the authority to manage the community's resources but were also the ones exploiting the poor

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'fear of God over gain'. What specific action can you take this week to care for the poor in your community?
tips: Consider helping a neighbor in need without expecting anything in return
Think about reducing your own financial burden to help others, like Nehemiah who refused his food allowance
Pray for the courage to act in the face of personal gain

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the example of Nehemiah who cared for the poor and ask for the courage to address injustice.
tips: Thank God for the example of Nehemiah who cared for the poor
Pray for the strength to refuse selfish gain and to care for others
Ask God to help you become a leader who addresses injustice in your community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 6:1-13 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Nehemiah and Sanballat/Geshem in verses 1-3 and Shemaiah's trap in verses 6-7.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I am doing a great work and cannot come down' (v.3) - a declaration of focus
Pay attention to the open letter accusation in verse 4 and Nehemiah's immediate response in verse 5
Listen for the tension in Shemaiah's words in verse 6-7: 'My life is in danger' but Nehemiah recognizes the trap

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT they are doing, WHERE it happens, and WHY they are acting in Nehemiah 6.
tips: Include Sanballat and Geshem's invitations to meet (v.1-3)
Note the open letter accusing Nehemiah of rebellion (v.4)
Describe Shemaiah's attempt to lure Nehemiah into the temple (v.6-7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Nehemiah's refusal (v.3), Shemaiah's trap (v.6-7), or the 52-day completion (v.13).
tips: Nehemiah's phrase 'I am doing a great work and cannot come down' shows his unwavering focus on God's task
Shemaiah's attempt to get Nehemiah into the temple (where laymen cannot go) is a clear trap to discredit him
The wall completed in 52 days is a powerful demonstration of God's work happening despite opposition

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about the importance of focused work and discernment in the face of opposition?
tips: The returned exiles needed a strong leader to rebuild their vulnerable community
Nehemiah shows that true leadership requires seeing through deception and staying focused on God's work
This passage foreshadows Christ's focus on His mission despite opposition

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The open letter accusation, why Shemaiah tried to lure Nehemiah into the temple, and the 52-day timeline.
tips: In ancient Israel, the temple was a holy place where only priests could enter; Shemaiah's attempt was a trap to discredit Nehemiah
The phrase 'I am doing a great work' (v.3) emphasizes the magnitude of the task but requires context to fully understand
The 52-day timeline (v.13) shows rapid progress of God's work despite opposition

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Nehemiah's refusal to distractions to your own life this week?
tips: Identify one distraction causing you to lose focus on God's work
Commit to setting that distraction aside for 26 hours to focus on the bigger picture
Pray for strength to see through deception and stay focused on God's mission

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the strength to discern plots and the focus to complete His work. Ask for courage to refuse distractions.
tips: Thank God for Nehemiah's example of refusing to be distracted by enemies
Pray for wisdom to recognize a trap when it's set for you
Ask God to help you complete the 'wall' of your life (spiritual growth) in the time He gives

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 7:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'the people' and the phrase 'the city is large but sparsely populated'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the people' in verses 3-7
Pay attention to the phrase 'the city is large but sparsely populated' in verse 14
The emotional tone shifts from urgency (securing the city) to reassurance (the census establishes identity)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (the returned exiles), WHAT (the census and registration by genealogy), WHERE (Jerusalem), WHEN (after the walls were completed), WHY (to establish community identity and secure the city), and HOW (by having Hanani and Hananiah lead the counting).
tips: Include the role of Hanani and Hananiah as governors (verses 2-3)
Note the detailed list of the people in the city (verses 3-7) and the fact that the city is large but sparsely populated (verse 14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the detailed genealogical list (verses 3-7), the phrase 'the city is large but sparsely populated' (verse 14), or the role of Hanani and Hananiah (verses 2-3)?
tips: The genealogical list (verses 3-7) shows the community's identity being restored through God's covenant
The phrase 'the city is large but sparsely populated' (verse 14) highlights the fragility of the community and the need for careful attention
The role of Hanani and Hananiah as gatekeepers (verses 2-3) emphasizes the importance of faithful leadership

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about the importance of community identity and security?
tips: Nehemiah emphasizes that the city's security depends on knowing the people (genealogy) and having faithful leaders (Hanani and Hananiah)
This establishes the community's identity in God's covenant, so they can be protected from spiritual enemies

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The purpose of the census? Why the city is 'large but sparsely populated'? The role of the Levites and gatekeepers?
tips: The census in this context is not just a headcount but a genealogical registry to ensure the community's identity and accountability (verses 3-7)
The phrase 'the city is large but sparsely populated' (verse 14) means the city has a large physical area but few people, indicating the community's vulnerability and the need for careful attention
The role of gatekeepers (verses 1-2) is to protect the city from external threats, which is a metaphor for spiritual protection

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice the careful registration of your identity in God's community this week?
tips: Consider an area in your life where you feel disconnected from your community (like a church group or family)
Take time to list your relationships and how you are connected to God's people (like the genealogical list in Nehemiah 7)
Practice being known by name in your community by actively engaging with others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the security He provides through Christ and ask for the community to be known by name and protected from spiritual enemies.
tips: Thank God for the security He provides through Christ (the gatekeepers and the census)
Pray for the courage to be part of a community where we are known by name
Ask God to protect the community from spiritual enemies by keeping them secure

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 8:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from the people weeping to the declaration of joy.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the people' (v.1, v.3, v.4) to show collective participation
Pay attention to the phrase 'the joy of the Lord is your strength' (v.10) and how it contrasts with the weeping (v.3)
The Levites' role in helping the people understand (v.3) is a key cultural detail

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Ezra, Levites, returned exiles) does WHAT (reads and explains the Law) WHERE (in Jerusalem) and WHY (to correct their failures and restore the Feast of Tabernacles).
tips: Include Ezra reading the Law from dawn to midday (v.1-3)
Note the Levites helping the people understand (v.3)
Mention the weeping of the people and the shift to celebration (v.3-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Ezra reading the Law (v.1-3), the people weeping (v.3), the declaration 'the joy of the Lord is your strength' (v.10), or the Feast of Tabernacles (v.12).
tips: The weeping shows deep conviction of sin, which is a powerful moment of humility
The immediate shift to joy after the weeping demonstrates God's grace in the midst of failure
The Feast of Tabernacles being restored as a sign of God's presence with them after the exile

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles through this passage?
tips: Nehemiah wanted to emphasize that the returned exiles must engage with the Law publicly and personally to restore their covenant relationship with God
The passage shows that understanding the Word leads to joy and restoration, not just guilt
The Feast of Tabernacles being celebrated again is a sign that God's presence and provision continue

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the Levites, the phrase 'the joy of the Lord is your strength', and the significance of the Feast of Tabernacles being restored.
tips: In ancient Israel, the Levites were responsible for teaching the Law and helping the people understand it
This phrase is a promise that God's joy (which comes from His presence) is the source of strength, especially when we are in weakness
The Feast of Tabernacles (Sukkot) was a reminder of the wilderness wanderings and the provision of God. It was not celebrated since Joshua's time (the conquest) because the people had been exiled and

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, choose one area where you've been dwelling in guilt or sadness and practice reading and understanding God's Word with the intention of experiencing the joy of the Lord as your strength.
tips: Read a short passage of Scripture (like Nehemiah 8:1-12) aloud and share it with a friend
Pray for the strength to move from guilt to joy in a specific situation
Plan to celebrate a small feast (like a simple meal with family) to experience the joy of the Lord

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His Word and His provision in your life. Ask for the strength to move from guilt to joy.
tips: Thank God for His Word and His provision in your life
Ask for the strength to share His Word with others
Pray for the joy of the Lord to be your strength when facing challenges

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 9:1-38 aloud, focusing on the collective prayer and confession.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'We have sinned' (v.3, v.38)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the people's remorse and the weight of the confession
Listen for the pattern of God's faithfulness and human failure

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is confessing, WHAT they are doing, WHERE this takes place, and WHY they are doing it.
tips: The returned exiles gather in Jerusalem for a fast and prayer (v.1-2)
The Levites lead a prayer that traces God's faithfulness from creation to the current exile (v.3-38)
They acknowledge their repeated unfaithfulness and the consequences (v.38)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the opening confession (v.3), the recounting of specific failures (v.3-38), or the closing plea for mercy (v.38)?
tips: The phrase 'We have sinned' in v.3 shows the collective responsibility and humility
The contrast between God's faithfulness and the people's repeated failures (v.15-16) highlights the depth of their sin
The closing statement: 'We are your people, and we have sinned' (v.38) is a powerful admission of accountability

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles through this passage of confession and covenant?
tips: The passage emphasizes that God's mercy has not been withdrawn despite their failures
Nehemiah is calling the exiles to a renewed covenant with God based on His faithfulness
This confession is a step toward restoration and a fresh commitment to live by the covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The nature of the confession, the historical context, or the theological implications?
tips: The phrase 'we have sinned' (v.3) is a collective confession that might be difficult to apply to modern contexts
The prayer recounts a long history of failure (v.15-38) which can be overwhelming to process
The concept of 'covenant' in this context (v.38) is a promise of God's mercy that requires ongoing obedience

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of present accountability from this passage to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you've been unfaithful and confess it to God this week
Commit to a specific action that shows accountability to God (e.g., prayer, service, or study)
Ask God to help you remember that He is faithful even when you fail

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of confession and covenant in this chapter.
tips: Thank God for His mercy that has not abandoned His people despite their failures
Pray for the courage to confess your sins and enter into a renewed covenant with Him
Ask God to help you live by the covenant with integrity and faithfulness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 10:1-39 aloud, paying attention to the collective vow and the list of specific commitments.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'We will not neglect the house of our God' (v.39)
Pay attention to the list of obligations starting at v. 1 (e.g., no intermarriage, Sabbath, sabbatical year)
The emotional tone shifts from solemn commitment to hopeful resolution

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the returned exiles, leaders, priests, Levites) does WHAT (signs a binding covenant), WHERE (the city of Jerusalem), and WHY (to ensure the community remains faithful and supports God's house).
tips: Include the specific commitments: no intermarriage, Sabbath, sabbatical year, temple tax, etc.
Note the role of the people in swearing an oath to walk in God's law
The covenant is signed to prevent the community from neglecting God's house

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the vow of the people (v. 29), the resolution 'We will not neglect the house of our God' (v. 39), or the list of specific obligations (v. 1-11).
tips: The phrase 'We will not neglect the house of our God' (v.39) is a powerful declaration of commitment
The detailed list of obligations (v. 1-11) shows practical faithfulness
The vow by the people to walk in God's law (v. 29) is a strong example of communal responsibility

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles through this passage?
tips: Nehemiah emphasizes the need for the community to recommit to God's law through specific actions
The covenant serves as a reminder that God's house must be maintained through the people's obedience
This passage foreshadows the new covenant in Christ, where believers are called to keep God's house (the church)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The specific obligations (e.g., no intermarriage), the sabbatical year, or the temple tax?
tips: 'No intermarriage' refers to avoiding marriage with non-Jews, which was a common issue in the post-exilic community
The sabbatical year (v. 12) is a land rest period that the exiles might have struggled to implement in a new city
The temple tax (v. 27) was a specific obligation to support the temple, which might have been confusing in the context of the temple's rebuilding

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'covenant commitment' to your life this week? Be specific about one commitment.
tips: Choose one specific obligation from the list (e.g., keep the Sabbath, support the church through tithes)
Think about how this commitment will impact your community
Commit to a small step of obedience, like praying for the temple or helping a neighbor

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His covenant and ask for strength to keep the commitments.
tips: Thank God for the written covenant that binds us to Him
Pray for courage to avoid intermarriage or other specific obligations
Ask for the community to be united in supporting God's house

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 11:1-39 aloud, paying attention to the names of the people and the process of casting lots.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the sons of...' (e.g., 'sons of Zadok', 'sons of the Levites')
Pay attention to the emotional tone of community building and the sense of divine order in the casting of lots

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the returned exiles), WHAT (assigning lots to repopulate Jerusalem), WHERE (Jerusalem and surrounding areas), and WHY (to establish a functioning community after the city's rebuilding).
tips: Include the leaders living in the city and the rest casting lots for one in ten to dwell in Jerusalem
Note the list of inhabitants from Judah, Benjamin, the priests, Levites, and gatekeepers
Mention that the city is being rebuilt as a community

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the casting of lots (v.1-2), the list of the people (v.3-39), or the phrase 'those who volunteered are blessed by the people' (v.2)?
tips: The casting of lots shows a fair and divine method for repopulating the city without bias
The list of names (e.g., 'the sons of Zadok' in v.1) demonstrates the diversity and commitment of the returned exiles
The phrase 'those who volunteered are blessed by the people' (v.2) highlights the community's response to sacrifice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about the importance of community and repopulating Jerusalem?
tips: Nehemiah emphasizes that the city's revival requires active participation and voluntary sacrifice from the community
The casting of lots ensures fairness and divine order in the repopulation process
This foreshadows the church being built on the foundation of willing service

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The casting of lots? The list of names? The meaning of 'one in ten'?
tips: 'Casting lots' was a common practice in ancient times for decision-making, but Nehemiah uses it to show a divine order for the city's repopulation
The chapter lists the names of many people (v.3-39) to show the community structure, but it's a record for administrative purposes
The phrase 'one in ten' (v.1) means that 10% of the people would be required to move to Jerusalem to ensure the city is populated without overwhelming it

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the principle of voluntary sacrifice to repopulate your community this week?
tips: Identify a small group or project where you can make a voluntary sacrifice (e.g., time, resources) to help build community
Use the casting lots method for a decision that requires fairness and divine order (e.g., choosing a leader for a small group)
Think about how the people in Jerusalem were blessed by their sacrifice and how you can be blessed by your own sacrifice

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the community He builds through voluntary sacrifice. Ask for courage to be part of the rebuilding.
tips: Thank God for the church as the new Jerusalem built on living stones
Pray for the courage to make sacrifices for the community, even when it's costly
Ask God to help you see the community you are part of and how you can contribute

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 12:1-36 aloud, focusing on the description of the processions and the joy of the dedication.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the joy of Jerusalem' (v.36)
Pay attention to the names of the priests and Levites (v.1-10) which show the restoration of the temple service
The phrase 'the gatekeepers' (v.40) and 'the singers' (v.41) are emphasized as the two processions meeting at the temple

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the returned exiles and their families), WHAT (the dedication of the walls of Jerusalem with two processions of singers and gatekeepers), WHERE (Jerusalem), and WHY (to celebrate the completion of the wall and the restoration of worship after the return from exile).
tips: Include the two processions of singers and gatekeepers walking in opposite directions (v.41-43)
Note the sacrifices and the joy that is heard from afar (v.36)
Mention the support for the Levites and priests from the people (v.40-41)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the two processions meeting at the temple (v.41-43), the joy of Jerusalem heard from afar (v.36), or the support for the singers and gatekeepers (v.40-41).
tips: The two processions meeting at the temple symbolizes unity and the coming together of all people in worship
The joy of Jerusalem being heard from afar shows the far-reaching impact of worship and the glory of God
The people's commitment to support the singers and gatekeepers demonstrates the community's love for the ministry

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to the returned exiles about the dedication of the walls?
tips: Nehemiah wanted to emphasize that the dedication of the walls was a joyful event that restored the temple worship and brought the community together
The passage shows that the exiles have been restored and are now actively participating in worship and service
This dedication is a picture of the church's worship ascending to heaven and the gathering of all nations in Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the Levites and priests, the meaning of the two processions, or the phrase 'the joy of Jerusalem is heard from afar'?
tips: The term 'Levites' in this context refers to the servants of the temple, but the passage lists specific families (e.g., the sons of Levi) to show the restoration of the temple service
The two processions walking in opposite directions meet at the temple to symbolize the unity of the people and the coming together of all in worship
The phrase 'the joy of Jerusalem is heard from afar' (v.36) describes the overwhelming joy that spread beyond the city walls, indicating the power of worship to affect the entire community and beyond

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of joyful worship and supporting the ministers in your life this week?
tips: Identify one way you can actively support the worship leaders in your church this week
Practice joyful worship by singing and praising God with your family or group
Take time to thank God for the joy of worship and the community that supports it

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the dedication of the walls and the restoration of worship in Jerusalem. Ask for the joy of worship and the unity of the community.
tips: Thank God for the dedication of the walls and the restoration of worship in Jerusalem
Ask for the courage to participate in worship and to support the ministers in your church
Pray for the unity of the community and the spreading of joy that is heard from afar

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nehemiah 13:1-33 aloud, paying attention to the urgency in Nehemiah's actions and the specific terms: Tobiah, Levites, Sabbath, foreign wives.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I went up' (Nehemiah's actions) in verses 1-2, 15-16, 21-22
Pay attention to the emotional tone of urgency and anger in verses 1-2 and 21-22
Listen for the specific terms: 'Tobiah', 'Levites', 'Sabbath', 'foreign wives'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Nehemiah and the returned exiles) does WHAT (addresses abuses), WHERE (in Jerusalem), and WHY (to restore God's house and covenant order).
tips: Include Tobiah being given a temple chamber (v.1-2)
Note the Levites leaving their posts (v.15-16)
Describe the Sabbath commerce and intermarriage (v.17-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Nehemiah's immediate action upon seeing Tobiah in the temple chamber (v.1-2), the rebuke to the Levites for neglecting their posts (v.15-16), or shutting the gates on Sabbath (v.21-22).
tips: Nehemiah's immediate action upon seeing Tobiah in the temple chamber (v.1-2) shows his commitment to God's house
The rebuke to the Levites for neglecting their posts (v.15-16) highlights the need for accountability
Shutting the gates on Sabbath (v.21-22) is a radical step to restore the Sabbath

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nehemiah trying to communicate to returned exiles through this passage?
tips: Nehemiah's goal was to restore the temple and the covenant community from backsliding
The returned exiles must live in obedience to God's laws (Sabbath, marriage, Levitical duties)
This passage pictures Christ's zeal for cleansing the temple

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Nehemiah's return to Jerusalem after the initial rebuilding, Tobiah's role, and the Sabbath commerce.
tips: Nehemiah's return to Jerusalem after the initial rebuilding: He was the governor who had just completed the wall (ch. 1-10) and then came back to address internal abuses
Tobiah's role: He was a former enemy of the Jews (as the governor of the province of Judah) and his presence in the temple was a violation of the temple's sanctity
Sabbath commerce: In ancient Israel, the Sabbath was a sign of the covenant, but Nehemiah shut the gates to prevent trade on Sabbath

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you restore the Sabbath as a holy day in your life this week?
tips: Choose one day this week to be free from work and digital devices (like the Sabbath)
Plan to rest and worship without the distractions of commerce
Share your Sabbath rest with a friend

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the restoration of God's house and the purity of the covenant community.
tips: Thank God for His authority to cleanse and restore His people
Ask for courage to confront sin in the community like Nehemiah did
Pray for the restoration of the Sabbath and marriage purity in your life
